The average paper length does depend on the discipline field. When I was in law school, the average length was 2,000 words for most essays and 3,000 for end-of-module papers. As you can imagine, there is a premium in law for being concise and on-point -- the idea that the lawyer is getting paid to solve the client's legal problems AND most court hearings give only 3 minutes each round of speaking to each side. However, it's also frequent enough that some sadistic law professor would set a 100-word limit for a summary of a 40-page case report -- just to weed out the chaff from the wheat of the class, so to speak. That really is even more painful to endure than a 5,000-word paper. If memory serves, the longest academic paper I've ever written was for my first degree in psychology and statistics, which was at 10,000 words or so. For my law final paper, it was only 6,000 words.
